ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Continued study of basic grammar and vocabulary in MSA.
I learned about more complex sentence structures, how to tell time, past and future, and case endings.
How to have conversations in intermediate arabic, the grammatical parts of a sentence, adjectival sentences, how to read newspapers and short stories
I learned how to speak Arabic much better.
I learned Arabic grammar and sentence structure as well as the best ways to learn and apply Arabic vocabulary.
Arabic language and grammar. Little speaking skills.
I learned how to hold small conversations in Arabic and expand my vocabulary.

Skills in understanding root words in Arabic; speaking in the past, future, and present perfect; negating the past and future; cultural events and phrases in the Egyptian dialect; I'm definitely missing some more here. Every time I finish a language class at Yale I'm amazed by how much I genuinely learn from only ~13 weeks of instruction.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths - weekly plan published sunday, making getting ahead easy. Professor Randa is very flexible and a terrific teacher. 

Weaknesses - feedback at times unclear, conversation partners had frequent scheduling issues, and grading was unclear.

The strength of this course was Ustadha Randa. A really great professor who is fun and very kind. Arabic is a difficult language, but now I can carry a conversation (with my fellow beginner peers) in Arabic without much challenge. There is a lot of material to learn though and I feel like we didn't go as in-depth as we could have on some of the subjects.
Very little interaction in Arabic. Very preachy

strengths: engaging material

weaknesses: too much at once; a lot of content that was expected to be memorized/understood with minimal practice

Strengths: a lot of opportunities to speak the language, fun friday assignments that I can complete anywhere, good mixture between types of teaching in class (presentation slides, chalk board, talking)

Weaknesses: Have more instruction with literary sources, have opportunities for extra credit, decrease difficulty of tests or maybe better prepare us for them by giving us practice ones. I felt that Arabic 110 didn't properly prepare me for this class because the former was easy and the latter was very challenging. This class was a big drain on my mental health because the homework took so much time and it felt like no matter how much effort i put into the class it wouldn't change my academic standing.

The strengths of this course was the emphasis on collaboration and the native language partners that we had. The weakness of this course was the heavy reliance on the Al Kitaab Arabic book that dictated how we learned and the content we learned.

Course is seriously disorganised. Attempts to address this are short lived. 
This outsourcing of speaking practice is problematic too. 
The italki experiment came at the expense of our learning experience.

Strengths in this class include being super engaging. However, a weakness is that it goes very fast which makes learning grammar a little difficult. As long as you constantly ask questions and be engaged, then confusion be prevented.

Strengths- instructional time devoted mainly to speaking in Arabic, instructional time sometimes involved reviewing missed homework questions, and tests/quizzes were usually brief and not the brunt of our grade.
Weaknesses- there could be more room for practicing casual conversational skills during instructional time.

I liked that students were given a weekly schedule prior to the week starting. This helped me plan my week and know how much time I would have to commit to the class that week. The class could be improved if there was a greater focus on spoken Arabic and forming sentences.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to students with deep experience and interest in Arabic.
If you've already taken ARBC 110, 120 is more of the same. If you like 110, take 120 .

I would recommend it if the student wants to learn how to speak the language. However, I 'd advise them that it's going to take 3 or more hours a day and acceptance that they will not do as well grade-wise as they might've hoped.
Only if they are passionate about Arabic
Yes, if they have interest in Arabic and are willing to put in a lot more time outside of daily class in order to really pick up the language.

Arabic is an awesome language, but this class was so unorganised, especially towards the end (extenuating circumstances, but still). 
Lack of support!
Yes I would recommend this course because it helped me gain a deeper love for the Arabic language.

I'd recommend this course to any students having completed L1 Arabic or who have experience with Semitic languages. The workload is definitely pretty intense and time-consuming (most of my friends in this course spent about 2 hours a day doing the homework), but if you have a real passion/interest/commitment to Arabic you'll find the course to be rewarding.
